description.text: A view of two wings of Charleville Hotel, some persons carrying their luggage, empty chairs lying in a corner of the lawn and a carriage unloading luggage of passengers.

location.name: Delhi / The Priya Paul Collection of Popular Art
Delhi / The Priya Paul Collection of Popular Art

rights.text: Copyrighted. Copyright with the original artists and publishers.

ext:item.ext:value: description-en: A view of two wings of Charleville Hotel, some persons carrying their luggage, empty chairs lying in a corner of the lawn and a carriage unloading luggage of passengers. (gs)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: The hill stations were where European men could find suitable wives, and children could be nurtured in surroundings that would assure their "Europeaness." The "season" was heavily scheduled with both official and unofficial balls, picnics, fetes, children's parties, etc. The "season" would last anything from four to six months, and the colonial community would take up residence in the hills either in rented houses or hotels. It is no surprise, therefore, that many of the postcards in the Priya Paul collection are of hill station hotels, for the Charleville Hotel in Mussoorie featured on this postcard. (Shashwati Talukdar)(gs)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: The Charleville was a European-only hotel, patronized by Queen Mary in 1906, and today houses a training academy for the elite recruits of the Indian government's administrative services. The arrangement of the buildings and their facade is imposing, yet intimate. With a well ordered lawn in the middle, smooth enough to play croquet in, it has buildings facing each other, inviting social interaction rather than forbidding it, albeit through a sanctioned conduit that also subtly encourages surveillance. (Shashwati Talukdar)(gs)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: Mussoorie had a reputation for leisure unfettered by official censure, in contrast to Simla which was much more restrained by bureaucratic protocol. An army medical officer recalled at the turn of the century that the hotel rang a (warning) bell at 6 a.m. to alert residents to return to their rooms, presumably after an evening of debauchery, to avoid scandal. (Shashwati Talukdar)(gs)

related literature: Kenny, Judith 1995. "Climate, Race, and Imperial Authority: The Symbolic Landscape of the British Hill Station in India." In Annals of the Association of American Geographers 85, no. 4 (1995): 694-714. (gs)
related literature: Mathur S. 2007. "India by Design: Colonial History and Cultural Display". Berkeley, Los Angeles, London: University of California Press; pp. 230. (gs)
related literature: Mitchell, W. J. T. 2002 "Imperial Landscape." In Landscape and Power, W. J. T Mitchell, 5-34. Chicago and London: The University of Chicago Press. (gs)

related literature: Pinney, Christpher 1995. “Moral Topophilia: The Significations of Landscape in Indian Oleographs" in The Anthropology of Landscape, ed. Erie Hirsch and Michael O'Hanlon. Oxford: Oxford University Press.

related literature: Talukdar, Shashwati 2010. "Picturing Mountains As Hills. Hill Station Postcards and the Tales They Tell" http://www.tasveergharindia.net/cmsdesk/essay/102/index.html, last accessed 2011-01-07. (gs)

Mussoorie had a reputation for leisure unfettered by official censure, in contrast to Simla which was much more restrained by bureaucratic protocol. An army medical officer recalled at the turn of the century that the hotel rang a (warning) bell at 6 a.m. to alert residents to return to their rooms, presumably after an evening of debauchery, to avoid scandal.

The hill stations were where European men could find suitable wives, and children could be nurtured in surroundings that would assure their "Europeaness." The "season" was heavily scheduled with both official and unofficial balls, picnics, fetes, children's parties, etc. The "season" would last anything from four to six months, and the colonial community would take up residence in the hills either in rented houses or hotels. It is no surprise, therefore, that many of the postcards in the Priya Paul collection are of hill station hotels, for the Charleville Hotel in Mussoorie featured on this postcard.

The Charleville was a European-only hotel, patronized by Queen Mary in 1906, and today houses a training academy for the elite recruits of the Indian government's administrative services. The arrangement of the buildings and their facade is imposing, yet intimate. With a well ordered lawn in the middle, smooth enough to play croquet in, it has buildings facing each other, inviting social interaction rather than forbidding it, albeit through a sanctioned conduit that also subtly encourages surveillance.
